Supported Cu catalysts are widely studied for the hydrogenation of CO2 to dimethyl ether (DME). However, they suffer from insufficient durability and DME selectivity. Herein, we overcome these issues by modulating the gallium species and hydrophobic methyl groups to obtain a silica-supported copper catalyst, achieving a Cu/Ga-SiO2-Me catalyst with significantly improved DME selectivity and catalyst durability. Characterizations of the catalysts showed that the gallium species electronically modulated the Cu nanoparticles, resulting in abundant Cu δ+ species in the catalyst, which minimized the reverse water-gas shift reaction and thus reduced CO selectivity. In addition, the methyl groups contributed to the rapid removal of water from the catalyst surface, which hindered Cu sintering and accelerated catalysis. Consequently, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me exhibited a CO2 conversion of 9.7%, selectivities of DME and methanol of 59.3% and 28.4%, and CO selectivity of only 11.3%. The strategy used in this study may provide rational guidance for improving current industrial catalysts. Keywords Hydrogenation of CO2 Copper catalyst Hydrophobic modulation Gallium promoter Catalyst stability 1 Introduction The selective conversion of CO2 and H2 into valuable chemicals and fuels is a promising route for carbon recycling [1–6]. Multiple routes have been developed for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [7], higher alcohols [8,9], dimethyl ether (DME) [10], aromatics [11], hydrocarbons [12–14], and olefins [3,15]. Among these products, DME is attractive because it is nontoxic and noncorrosive and has been used as a platform chemical in industry, a carrier for hydrogen, and an additive for fuels [10,16–18]. For example, DME can be directly converted into light olefins over zeolite catalysts [19] and reformed with steam to produce hydrogen [20]. Both exhibit significantly higher efficiencies than methanol. A series of catalysts has been synthesized for the direct hydrogenation of CO2 to DME via cascade catalysis involving methanol synthesis and methanol condensation to DME over a supported copper catalyst (e.g., Cu-ZnO) and an acid catalyst (e.g., HZSM-5 zeolite), respectively [17,21,22]. However, high DME selectivity was only achieved at low conversion of CO2, resulting in poor one-pass productivity [23]. When the CO2 conversion increased, abundant by-products of CO, methanol, and hydrocarbons were produced. A recent trend is CO2-to-DME conversion over bifunctional catalysts, such as acid oxide-supported copper nanoparticles, but their performance is still insufficient [24,25]. In addition, the copper nanoparticles were sintered during catalysis, resulting in poor durability [22,25]. In this study, we overcome these limitations by developing a highly active, selective, and durable copper nanoparticle catalyst for converting CO2 to DME. This was achieved by loading Cu nanoparticles onto hydrophobic and Ga-modified silica supports. The Ga-modified silica provided moderate acidity for methanol dehydration to DME, which hindered deep dehydration to hydrocarbons. Importantly, the hydrophobic catalyst surface efficiently hinders the sintering of the Cu nanoparticles, which is usually triggered by water and methanol. Consequently, under the following reaction conditions (6000 mL gcat −1 h−1, 3 MPa, 240 °C), the CO2 conversion of 9.7%, DME and methanol selectivities of 59.3% and 28.4%, and CO selectivity of only 11.3% were obtained. In a continuous evaluation for 100 h, the performance was well maintained without any deactivation trend, outperforming the general supported Cu catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, > 99%), diethoxydimethylsilane (DEMS), methanol, ethanol, and (Al(NO3)3·9H2O) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Company. Ammonia solution (NH3·H2O, 28 wt%), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), gallium nitrate nonahydrate(Ga(NO3)3·9H2O) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Feed gases (containing H2/CO2/Ar, H2/N2, H2/Ar, CO, Ar, etc.) were supplied by Hangzhou Jingong special gas Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation As a typical run for the synthesis of Cu/SiO2, 7.32 g of TEOS was dropped into a mixed liquor containing 100 mL of ethanol, 100 mL of water, and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia. After stirring at room temperature for 12 h, an aqueous Cu(NO3)2 solution (30 mL, 4.82 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia were further added into the aforementioned mixed liquor. After stirring at room temperature for another 24 h, the suspension was filtered and washed with pure water for 5 times, and subsequently dried at 100 °C for 10 h and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. The Ga/SiO2 catalyst were synthesized following similar procedures by only using Ga(NO3)3·9H2O without Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in the starting solution. The Cu/Ga x -SiO2-20Me catalysts (x represents the molar ratio of Ga to Cu in the initial feed) with different Ga loadings were synthesized by co-hydrolysis method, with initial feed molar ratio of Ga to Cu at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0, respectively. As a typical run for the synthesis of Cu/Ga0.2-SiO2-20Me with Ga/Cu molar ratio at 0.2, 6.66 g of TEOS and 1.18 g of DEMS were dropped into a mixed liquor containing 100 mL of ethanol, 100 mL of water, and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia. After stirring at room temperature for 12 h, an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2 and Ga(NO3)3 (30 mL, 4.82 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 1.67 g of Ga(NO3)3·9H2O) and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia were further added into the aforementioned mixed liquor. After stirring at room temperature for another 24 h, the suspension was filtered and washed with pure water 5 times, and subsequently dried at 100 °C for 10 h and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the Cu/Ga0.2-SiO2-20Me catalyst. The Cu/Ga x - SiO2-20Me samples with different Ga loadings at molar ratio of Ga to Cu at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 were synthesized following the same procedures excepting using 1.18, 4.18, 8.36, and 16.72 g of Ga(NO3)3·9H2O in the starting solution. The Cu/SiO2-20Me catalyst without gallium species were synthesized following similar procedures without using Ga(NO3)3·9H2O in the starting solution. The Cu/Al-SiO2-20Me catalyst was synthesized following similar procedures by using Al(NO3)3·9H2O instead of Ga(NO3)3·9H2O in the starting solution. The Cu/Ga-SiO2-yMe catalysts (y represents the molar fraction of methyl modified Si to the total content of Si species) with different amounts of methyl group were synthesized by co-hydrolysis method, with initial feed molar ratio of DEMS to (DEMS+TEOS) (DEMS/(DEMS+TEOS)) at 10%, 20%, 30%, and 50%, respectively. As a typical run for the synthesis of Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me (Ga/Cu molar ratio at 1.0) with DEMS/(DEMS+TEOS) molar ratio at 20%, 6.66 g of TEOS and 1.18 g of DEMS were dropped into a mixed liquor containing 100 mL of ethanol, 100 mL of water, and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia. After stirring at room temperature for 12 h, an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2 and Ga(NO3)3 (30 mL, 4.82 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 8.36 g of Ga(NO3)3·9H2O) and 10 mL of aqueous ammonia were further added into the aforementioned mixed liquor. After stirring at room temperature for another 24 h, the suspension was filtered and washed with pure water 5 times, and subsequently dried at 100 °C for 10 h and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst. As a typical run, 0.2 g of the as-prepared catalyst was fixed in the middle of the reactor. The catalyst was in situ reduced in 10 vol% H2 flow (20 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 8 h, then the gas was switched to a mixture of CO2 and hydrogen at appropriate pressure (e.g., 3 MPa) and temperature (e.g., 210–300 °C) to start the reaction. The gaseous products were analyzed by two online gas chromatographs with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, FULI 9790) and a flame ionization detector (FID, FULI 9790), respectively. The CO2 conversion, products selectivity, and the space-time yield (STY) of CH3OH were calculated according to the equations in the following: (1) X (CO2) = (n in(CO2) – n out(CO2))/n in(CO2) × 100% (2) S (DME) = n out(DME)/(n in(CO2) – n out(CO2)) × 100% (3) S (MeOH) = n out(MeOH)/(n in(CO2) – n out(CO2)) × 100% (4) S (CO) = n out(CO)/(n in(CO2) – n out(CO2)) × 100% (5) S (CH4) = n out(CH4)/(n in(CO2) – n out(CO2)) × 100% where n is the mole rate (mol h−1) of CO2 and products (DME, MeOH, CO, and CH4). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results The Cu/SiO2, Cu/Ga-SiO2, and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts were synthesized using a cohydrolysis method. Fig. 1(A) shows the XRD patterns of the prereduced Cu/SiO2, Cu/Ga-SiO2, and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me samples, with diffraction peaks at 43.4° and 50.4° assigned to the metallic Cu phase (JCPDS 04-0836) [26]. Compared to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts exhibited additional peaks at 37.0° and 62.4°, respectively, which were indexed to the Cu2O phase (JCPDS 34–1354) [27], indicating that adding gallium species formed Cu2O. The N2 sorption isotherms of these samples showed type–IV curves with a hysteresis loop between the relative pressure of 0.70 < P/P 0 < 0.95, indicating mesoporosity (Fig. 1(B)) [26]. Cu/SiO2 afforded a surface area of 148 m2 g−1. Interestingly, after adding Ga, the surface areas of the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts were increased, reaching 188 and 191 m2 g−1, respectively (Table S1). Fig. 1(C) shows the temperature-programmed reduction test (H2-TPR) with hydrogen. The Cu/SiO2 catalyst gave a signal at 235 °C correlated to the reduction of CuO into metallic Cu [28]. However, the reduction peaks shifted towards higher temperatures at 273 and 254 °C over the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts, respectively, suggesting an enhanced metal-support interaction compared with the Ga-free sample. Electron micrography was used to directly observe the morphologies of the catalysts, as shown in Figs. 2(a), (b) , and S1. Cu/SiO2 showed an accumulation of silica spheres with sizes of 130–570 nm, which is consistent with previous results [29]. After the addition of Ga, the sizes of the silica spheres were significantly reduced to 50–210 nm, as confirmed by the SEM images of the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts (Figs. 2(b) and S1, respectively). Figs. 2(c) and (d) show TEM images of the reduced Cu/SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts. The Cu/SiO2 catalyst showed a uniform distribution of Cu over the spherical SiO2 with a narrow distribution at ~3.2 nm (Figs. 2(c) and S2). The Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst exhibited slightly larger Cu nanoparticles (~4.0 nm, Fig. 2(d)). Gallium species are observed in the elemental maps surrounding the silica spheres (Fig. S3). CO-adsorption DRIFTS was employed to investigate the chemical states of Cu in the different catalysts. As shown in Figs. 3(D)–(F) , Cu/SiO2, Cu/Ga-SiO2, and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts showed two chemisorbed CO bands at 2150–2155 and 2104–2107 cm−1, which corresponded to the linear stretching of Cu δ+−CO and Cu0−CO species, respectively [27,30]. Notably, Cu/SiO2 exhibited a main peak at ~2104 cm−1, suggesting the presence of Cu0 species. By contrast, abundant Cu δ+ species appeared at the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts. We calculated the ratio of Cu δ+/Cu0 in different samples by fitting the peaks of adsorbed CO on the Cu surface [30], yielding the value of 0.44 for Cu/SiO2 and 9.67 and 8.75 for the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts, respectively. These results confirm that adding gallium species is favorable for forming Cu δ+ species, which agrees with the H2-TPR results. Figs. 3(A)–(C) show in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with Auger electron spectroscopy (XPS-AES) spectra of the reduced Cu/SiO2, Cu/Ga-SiO2, and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts. All these samples exhibited peaks with binding energy at ~918.1 and ~914.4 eV, which were attributed to the Cu0 and Cu δ+ species on silica, respectively [31,32]. Compared with Cu/SiO2, the Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me samples exhibited additional signals at ~910.0 eV, which were assigned to the Cu α+ species from GaCuO x [33,34]. According to the peak areas, the ratio of Cu δ+ to Cu0 over the Cu/SiO2 was lower than those of Cu/Ga-SiO2 and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts, giving a similar tendency as the CO-adsorption DRIFTS results. 3.2 Catalytic performances The evaluations of catalysts in the hydrogenation of CO2 were performed in a fixed-bed reactor under the following reaction conditions (6000 mL g−1 h−1, 240 °C, 3 MPa) using a feed gas of Ar/CO2/H2 with the volume ratio of 4/24/72. The CO2 conversion and product selectivity data are summarized in Fig. 4(A) . The Cu/SiO2 catalyst afforded CO2 conversion of 5.5%, methanol selectivity of 60.0%, and CO selectivity of 40.0%, with undetectable DME. In the reaction over the Cu/Ga-SiO2 catalyst, both the CO2 conversion and DME selectivity were improved to 8.0% and 37.4%, respectively. In this case, the selectivities for methanol and CO are 45.7% and 15.0%, respectively. Furthermore, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst exhibited a higher CO2 conversion of 9.7% with a DME selectivity of 59.3%. A trade-off exists between CO2 conversion and DME selectivity during the reaction. Fig. 4(B) summarizes the DME selectivity as a function of CO2 conversion in previous studies [10,16,17,21,22,24,25,35–38]. Tandem catalysts for methanol synthesis and dehydration yield unsatisfactory results. For example, a physical mixture of Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 and H-ZSM-5 zeolites afforded a CO2 conversion of 10.9%, but the DME selectivity was < 40.0% [17], and the Pd/SiO2-SZ catalyst even showed CO2 conversion only of 5.5% with DME selectivity of 19.3% [36]. Furthermore, the Cu/Al-SiO2-20Me synthesized via a similar preparation method of Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst afforded a CO2 conversion of 14.5%, but the DME selectivity was only 3.0% with large amounts of CO and C2 + hydrocarbon by-products, with selectivities of 40.0% and 41.6%, respectively (Table S2). In comparison, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst simultaneously exhibited high CO2 conversion and DME selectivity relative to the previous catalysts. Notably, the byproducts were CO and methanol in the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyzed CO2-to-DME conversion, which can be easily recycled to produce DME. The selectivity for hydrocarbon products from deep hydrogenation/deoxygenation was lower than 1.0% in this process. Moreover, we have also performed the hydrogenation of CO2 reactions under reaction temperatures of 210–300 °C (6000 mL gcat −1 h−1, 3 MPa, 240 °C, Ar/CO2/H2 volume ratio of 4/24/72). As shown in Fig. 4(C), at 210 °C, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst afforded a CO2 conversion of 5.3%, DME and methanol selectivities of 38.7%, and 51.0%, with CO selectivity of 10.2%, respectively. Raising the reaction temperature to 300 °C gradually increased the CO2 conversion to 18.1%. The DME selectivities reached the maximum of 59.3% at 240 °C. Further raising the reaction temperature decreased the DME selectivity owing to the enhanced reactions of the reverse water-gas shift and deep hydrogenation to form methane. Therefore, we evaluated the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to DME at the optimal temperature of 240 °C for 100 h. As shown in Fig. 4(D), Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me exhibited a constant CO2 conversion of 9.7%, with the DME, methanol, CO, and CH4 selectivities of ~59.5%, 28.5%, 11.0%, and 1.0%, respectively. In the equivalent test for 100 h, the CO2 conversion over Cu/Ga-SiO2 catalyst was decreased from ~8.0% to 5.5% (Fig. S4) because of the sintering of Cu nanoparticles (Fig. S5). TEM characterization of the spent Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst showed an average Cu nanoparticle size of ~4.5 nm (Fig. S6), which is comparable to that of the as-reduced catalyst, suggesting improved stability of the Cu nanoparticles. 3.3 Reaction processes We collected in situ DRIFT spectra of CO2 hydrogenation over Cu/SiO2, Cu/Ga-SiO2, and Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts to identify the reaction process. In the tests, the catalysts interacted with feed gases (H2/CO2 at 3/1, volume ratio) at 240 °C for 2 h under ambient pressure. As shown in Figs. 5(A)–(C) , all catalysts showed main bands at 2928 and 2848 cm−1 assigned to the vibrations of C–H from methoxy (CH3O•) and formate (HCOO•) species, respectively [39–41]. These are the general intermediates formed during the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol process [2,42,43]. By contrast, Cu/Ga-SiO2 showed weakened signals of methoxy and formate species, with an additional band at 2893 cm−1, which was related to the vibration of C–H from the DME product [44], revealing a successive transformation process for the dehydration of methanol to DME. In addition, Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me exhibited extremely weak bands for methoxy, formate, and DME species, which could be attributed to the rapid conversion and desorption of these species. These phenomena can be reasonably assigned to the hydrophobicity of the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst, as evidenced by the water sorption and water droplet contact angle tests (Figs. 5(D)–(F)). The stability of the methyl groups on the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst was evaluated at the reaction temperature in a hydrogen atmosphere, and the possible species from methyl leaching were analyzed using a mass spectrometer. As shown in Fig. 6(A) , no signals corresponding to carbon-containing species were detected after 24 h, suggesting the high stability of the methyl groups. The spent Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst exhibited a water desorption peak at 130 °C in the water-TPD test (Fig. 6(B)), comparable to fresh Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me (Fig. 5(E)). In addition, the spent Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me exhibited a water droplet contact angle of 68° (Fig. 6(C)), which was similar to that of the fresh catalyst. We performed a thermogravimetric differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) analysis of the as-synthesized and spent Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6(D), the spent Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst exhibited three stages of weight loss, similar to those of the as-synthesized catalysts (Fig. S7). These samples showed similar weight loss at 450–600 °C, which was accompanied by an exothermic process. This was attributed to the oxidation of methyl groups [45,46], suggesting that the methyl groups were maintained during the reaction. Based on the crucial role of gallium species and methyl groups in efficient CO2-to-DME conversion, we studied the influence of their content on performance. Fig. 7(A) shows the catalytic performances of the Cu/Ga x -SiO2-20Me catalysts with various Ga contents. In the absence of Ga, the Cu/SiO2-20Me catalyst afforded CO2 conversion of 7.5% and DME selectivity of only ~5.0%, with a high CO selectivity of 49.0%. Over the Cu/Ga x -SiO2-20Me catalysts with Ga/Cu molar ratios of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0, the DME selectivities were dramatically promoted to 47.0%, 51.0%, 59.3%, and 41.6% with CO2 conversions of 10.5%, 9.8%, 9.7%, and 7.1% owing to the acidity and structural properties (Figs. S8–S10). In these cases, the CO selectivities were dramatically suppressed to 11.3%–15.0%, owing to the considerably increased Cu δ+ species with simultaneously reduced Cu0 species by raising the gallium contents. This phenomenon was inconsistent with the function of different Cu species identified previously [27,47–49]. The Cu δ+ species were responsible for stabilizing CH3O• from decomposition into CO, while Cu0 species were the main active sites for reversed water-gas shift reaction to produce CO. In this case, Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me with a Ga/Cu molar ratio of ~1.0 was the optimum ratio in this study. We further evaluated the Cu/Ga-SiO2-yMe catalyst with different contents of methyl groups at 0%–50% (molar fraction of methyl-modified Si to the total content of Si species). The results are summarized in Fig. 7(B). With raising the content of methyl groups from 0% to 20%, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-yMe catalysts showed both enhanced CO2 conversion from 8.0% to 9.7% and DME selectivities from 37.4% to 59.3%, with simultaneously decreased methanol selectivities from 45.7% to 28.4%. These data indicated that modulation with methyl groups promoted the hydrogenation of CO2 and dehydration of methanol. However, with a further increase in the content of methyl groups from 20% to 50%, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-yMe catalysts exhibited decreased CO2 conversions from 9.7% to 7.5% with decreased MeOH selectivities from 28.4% to 24.2%, and DME selectivities from 59.3% to 54.1% gradually. Simultaneously, the selectivities for the undesired byproducts, CO and CH4, increased from 11.3% to 18.0% and 1.0% to 3.7%, respectively. These results suggest that the methyl groups improved the hydrophobicity of Cu/Ga-SiO2 (Figs. S11 and S12), which contributed to the rapid removal of water generated from the reactions and subsequently promoted CO2 conversion and DME selectivity. However, more methyl content in the catalysts (e.g., 50%) weakened the silica-Cu interaction, forming bulky Cu particles (Figs. S13–S18), decreasing the number of active sites, and causing partial deactivation. Therefore, the optimum ratio was the Cu/Ga-SiO2-Me catalyst with 20% methyl content. We further studied the synergism between the Cu and Ga species by regulating the mixing mechanisms of Cu/SiO2-20Me and Ga/SiO2-20Me, which simulated individuals with different hydrogenation and methanol dehydration functions, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7(C), the catalysts in a dual-bed manner with Ga/SiO2-20Me localized under Cu/SiO2-20Me afforded a CO2 conversion of 7.6% and DME selectivity of 40.0%. This CO2 conversion was similar to those of the bare Cu/SiO2-20Me catalyst, which produced methanol as the main product. For the catalysts with granule mixing methods (Cu/SiO2-20Me and Ga/SiO2-20Me were separately made into granules and then mixed in the bed for catalysis), the CO2 conversions were slightly enhanced to 8.4% and 8.6% with decreased DME selectivities of 33.0% and 39.0% over the catalysts with granule sizes of 20–40 and 60–80 meshes, respectively. The Cu/SiO2-20Me and Ga/SiO2-20Me catalysts in a powder mixing manner afforded a higher CO2 conversion of 8.8% and DME selectivity of 50%, which were higher than those in the other mixing manners but still slightly lower than those of the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst. Generally, the reaction intermediate (methanol) generated over Cu/SiO2 must have been transported in the gas phase and readsorbed onto the active sites of Ga/SiO2-20Me, where it is dehydrated into the DME product. The hydrophobic acid catalyst of Ga/SiO2-20Me is required for promoting dehydration, but the hydrophobicity also hinders the access of polar methanol to the catalysts (Figs. 7(D), S19–S24). This explains the reduced DME selectivity and high selectivity for methanol in the tests over the physically mixed catalysts. For the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me catalyst, the proximity of Cu and Ga species could simultaneously realize tandem reactions of hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol and dehydration of methanol to DME, where further transportation and readsorption of methanol intermedia to the hydrophobic catalyst was avoided. Moreover, the methyl groups efficiently removed the water generated in these two reactions, shifting the reaction equilibrium forward (Table S3 and Fig. S25). In this case, CO2 conversion and DME selectivity were both promoted over Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me and were higher than those of other silica-supported copper catalysts containing gallium species and hydrophobic methyl groups (Table S3). 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrated that the modulation of gallium species and hydrophobic methyl groups could significantly improve the performance of silica-supported copper catalysts in converting CO2 and H2 to DME, giving Cu/Ga-SiO2-Me catalysts with simultaneously improved CO2 conversion, DME selectivity, and catalyst durability. Characterizations of the catalysts reveal that the introduction of gallium species forms more Cu δ+ species, which efficiently hinders the reverse water-gas shift, and the methyl groups contribute to the diffusion of water from the catalysts, resulting in improved catalytic performance. This strategy may guide the design of more efficient catalysts for selective conversion of CO2 in the future. coredata.dc:description: Supported Cu catalysts are widely studied for the hydrogenation of CO2 to dimethyl ether (DME). However, they suffer from insufficient durability and DME selectivity. Herein, we overcome these issues by modulating the gallium species and hydrophobic methyl groups to obtain a silica-supported copper catalyst, achieving a Cu/Ga-SiO2-Me catalyst with significantly improved DME selectivity and catalyst durability. Characterizations of the catalysts showed that the gallium species electronically modulated the Cu nanoparticles, resulting in abundant Cu δ+ species in the catalyst, which minimized the reverse water-gas shift reaction and thus reduced CO selectivity. In addition, the methyl groups contributed to the rapid removal of water from the catalyst surface, which hindered Cu sintering and accelerated catalysis. Consequently, the Cu/Ga-SiO2-20Me exhibited a CO2 conversion of 9.7%, selectivities of DME and methanol of 59.3% and 28.4%, and CO selectivity of only 11.3%. The strategy used in this study may provide rational guidance for improving current industrial catalysts.
